conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to determine speed at t=60 seconds.
Graph shows acceleration (m/s^2) on y-axis and time (seconds) on x-axis.
Speed is the integral of acceleration over time, area under graph gives change in velocity.
Acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s^2 from t=0 to t=1 second.
Acceleration is constant at 2 m/s^2 from t=1 to t=4 seconds.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 2 to 0 m/s^2 from t=4 to t=5 seconds.
Acceleration is 0 m/s^2 from t=5 to t=55 seconds.
Acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s^2 from t=55 to t=56 seconds.
Acceleration is constant at -2 m/s^2 from t=56 to t=59 seconds.
Acceleration increases linearly from -2 to 0 m/s^2 from t=59 to t=60 seconds.
Calculate area from t=0 to t=1 second: triangle area is 1 m/s.
Calculate area from t=1 to t=4 seconds: rectangle area is 6 m/s.
Calculate area from t=4 to t=5 seconds: triangle area is 1 m/s.
Calculate area from t=5 to t=55 seconds: rectangle area is 0 m/s.
Calculate area from t=55 to t=56 seconds: triangle area is -1 m/s.
Calculate area from t=56 to t=59 seconds: rectangle area is -6 m/s.
Calculate area from t=59 to t=60 seconds: triangle area is -1 m/s.
Sum the areas: total area is 0 m/s.
Initial speed is 0 m/s; total change in velocity is 0 m/s, so final speed is 0 m/s.
Final speed of the elevator at t=60 seconds is 0 m/s.
